dom-audiotrack-sourcebuffer.name: sourceBuffer
dom-audiotrack-sourcebuffer.summary: The read-only AudioTrack property sourceBuffer returns the SourceBuffer that created the track, or null if the track was not created by a SourceBuffer or the SourceBuffer has been removed from the MediaSource.sourceBuffers attribute of its parent media source.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-audiotrack-sourcebuffer.title: AudioTrack.sourceBuffer

htmlmediaelement-extensions.name: buffered
htmlmediaelement-extensions.summary: The buffered read-only property of HTMLMediaElement objects returns a new static normalized TimeRanges object that represents the ranges of the media resource, if any, that the user agent has buffered at the moment the buffered property is accessed.
htmlmediaelement-extensions.title: HTMLMediaElement.buffered

htmlmediaelement-extensions.name: seekable
htmlmediaelement-extensions.summary: The seekable read-only property of HTMLMediaElement objects returns a new static normalized TimeRanges object that represents the ranges of the media resource, if any, that the user agent is able to seek to at the time seekable property is accessed.
htmlmediaelement-extensions.title: HTMLMediaElement.seekable

dom-mediasource-constructor.name: MediaSource
dom-mediasource-constructor.summary: The MediaSource() constructor of the MediaSource interface constructs and returns a new MediaSource object with no associated source buffers.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-constructor.title: MediaSource()

dom-mediasource-activesourcebuffers.name: activeSourceBuffers
dom-mediasource-activesourcebuffers.summary: The activeSourceBuffers read-only property of the MediaSource interface returns a SourceBufferList object containing a subset of the SourceBuffer objects contained within sourceBuffers â€” the list of objects providing the selected video track, enabled audio tracks, and shown/hidden text tracks.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-activesourcebuffers.title: MediaSource.activeSourceBuffers

dom-mediasource-addsourcebuffer.name: addSourceBuffer
dom-mediasource-addsourcebuffer.summary: The addSourceBuffer() method of the MediaSource interface creates a new SourceBuffer of the given MIME type and adds it to the MediaSource's sourceBuffers list. The new SourceBuffer is also returned.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-addsourcebuffer.title: MediaSource.addSourceBuffer()

dom-mediasource-clearliveseekablerange.name: clearLiveSeekableRange
dom-mediasource-clearliveseekablerange.summary: The clearLiveSeekableRange() method of the MediaSource interface clears a seekable range previously set with a call to setLiveSeekableRange().

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-clearliveseekablerange.title: MediaSource.clearLiveSeekableRange()

dom-mediasource-duration.name: duration
dom-mediasource-duration.summary: The duration property of the MediaSource interface gets and sets the duration of the current media being presented.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-duration.title: MediaSource.duration

dom-mediasource-endofstream.name: endOfStream
dom-mediasource-endofstream.summary: The endOfStream() method of the MediaSource interface signals the end of the stream.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-endofstream.title: MediaSource.endOfStream()

dom-mediasource-istypesupported.name: isTypeSupported
dom-mediasource-istypesupported.summary: The MediaSource.isTypeSupported() static method returns a boolean value which is true if the given MIME type and (optional) codec are likely to be supported by the current user agent.

notes: codecs string can contain any subset of optional parameters (should be all or none).
Errors if codecs string contains unexpected characters (should evaluate string up to character).

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 101, isTypeSupported() ignored codecs parameter options for av01 codecs (treating them as av1).

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 101, isTypeSupported() ignored codecs parameter options for av01 codecs (treating them as av1).

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

notes: codecs string can contain any subset of optional parameters (should be all or none).
Errors if codecs string contains unexpected characters (should evaluate string up to character).
codecs string can contain any subset of optional parameters (should be all or none).
Errors if codecs string contains unexpected characters (should evaluate string up to character).

dom-mediasource-istypesupported.title: MediaSource.isTypeSupported()

dom-mediasource-readystate.name: readyState
dom-mediasource-readystate.summary: The readyState read-only property of the MediaSource interface returns an enum representing the state of the current MediaSource. The three possible values are:

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-readystate.title: MediaSource.readyState

dom-mediasource-removesourcebuffer.name: removeSourceBuffer
dom-mediasource-removesourcebuffer.summary: The removeSourceBuffer() method of the MediaSource interface removes the given SourceBuffer from the SourceBuffers list associated with this MediaSource object.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-removesourcebuffer.title: MediaSource.removeSourceBuffer()

dom-mediasource-setliveseekablerange.name: setLiveSeekableRange
dom-mediasource-setliveseekablerange.summary: The setLiveSeekableRange() method of the MediaSource interface sets the range that the user can seek to in the media element.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-setliveseekablerange.title: MediaSource.setLiveSeekableRange()

dom-mediasource-sourcebuffers.name: sourceBuffers
dom-mediasource-sourcebuffers.summary: The sourceBuffers read-only property of the MediaSource interface returns a SourceBufferList object containing the list of SourceBuffer objects associated with this MediaSource.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-mediasource-sourcebuffers.title: MediaSource.sourceBuffers

mediasource.name: MediaSource
mediasource.summary: The MediaSource interface of the Media Source Extensions API represents a source of media data for an HTMLMediaElement object. A MediaSource object can be attached to a HTMLMediaElement to be played in the user agent.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

mediasource.title: MediaSource

dom-sourcebuffer-abort.name: abort
dom-sourcebuffer-abort.summary: The abort() method of the SourceBuffer interface aborts the current segment and resets the segment parser.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-abort.title: SourceBuffer.abort()

dom-sourcebuffer-appendbuffer.name: appendBuffer
dom-sourcebuffer-appendbuffer.summary: The appendBuffer() method of the SourceBuffer interface appends media segment data from an ArrayBuffer, a TypedArray or a DataView object to the SourceBuffer.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-appendbuffer.title: SourceBuffer.appendBuffer()

dom-sourcebuffer-appendwindowend.name: appendWindowEnd
dom-sourcebuffer-appendwindowend.summary: The appendWindowEnd property of the SourceBuffer interface controls the timestamp for the end of the append window, a timestamp range that can be used to filter what media data is appended to the SourceBuffer. Coded media frames with timestamps within this range will be appended, whereas those outside the range will be filtered out.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-appendwindowend.title: SourceBuffer.appendWindowEnd

dom-sourcebuffer-appendwindowstart.name: appendWindowStart
dom-sourcebuffer-appendwindowstart.summary: The appendWindowStart property of the SourceBuffer interface controls the timestamp for the start of the append window, a timestamp range that can be used to filter what media data is appended to the SourceBuffer. Coded media frames with timestamps within this range will be appended, whereas those outside the range will be filtered out.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-appendwindowstart.title: SourceBuffer.appendWindowStart

dom-sourcebuffer-audiotracks.name: audioTracks
dom-sourcebuffer-audiotracks.summary: The audioTracks read-only property of the SourceBuffer interface returns a list of the audio tracks currently contained inside the SourceBuffer.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-audiotracks.title: SourceBuffer.audioTracks

dom-sourcebuffer-buffered.name: buffered
dom-sourcebuffer-buffered.summary: The buffered read-only property of the SourceBuffer interface returns the time ranges that are currently buffered in the SourceBuffer as a normalized TimeRanges object.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-buffered.title: SourceBuffer.buffered

dom-sourcebuffer-changetype.name: changeType
dom-sourcebuffer-changetype.summary: The changeType() method of the SourceBuffer interface sets the MIME type that future calls to appendBuffer() should expect the new media data to conform to. This makes it possible to change codecs or container type mid-stream.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-changetype.title: SourceBuffer.changeType()

dom-sourcebuffer-mode.name: mode
dom-sourcebuffer-mode.summary: The mode property of the SourceBuffer interface controls whether media segments can be appended to the SourceBuffer in any order, or in a strict sequence.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-mode.title: SourceBuffer.mode

dom-sourcebuffer-remove.name: remove
dom-sourcebuffer-remove.summary: The remove() method of the SourceBuffer interface removes media segments within a specific time range from the SourceBuffer. This method can only be called when SourceBuffer.updating equals false. If SourceBuffer.updating is not equal to false, call SourceBuffer.abort().

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-remove.title: SourceBuffer.remove()

dom-sourcebuffer-texttracks.name: textTracks
dom-sourcebuffer-texttracks.summary: The textTracks read-only property of the SourceBuffer interface returns a list of the text tracks currently contained inside the SourceBuffer.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-texttracks.title: SourceBuffer.textTracks

dom-sourcebuffer-timestampoffset.name: timestampOffset
dom-sourcebuffer-timestampoffset.summary: The timestampOffset property of the SourceBuffer interface controls the offset applied to timestamps inside media segments that are appended to the SourceBuffer.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-timestampoffset.title: SourceBuffer.timestampOffset

dom-sourcebuffer-updating.name: updating
dom-sourcebuffer-updating.summary: The updating read-only property of the SourceBuffer interface indicates whether the SourceBuffer is currently being updated â€” i.e. whether an SourceBuffer.appendBuffer(), SourceBuffer.appendStream(), or SourceBuffer.remove() operation is currently in progress.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-updating.title: SourceBuffer.updating

dom-sourcebuffer-videotracks.name: videoTracks
dom-sourcebuffer-videotracks.summary: The videoTracks read-only property of the SourceBuffer interface returns a list of the video tracks currently contained inside the SourceBuffer.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebuffer-videotracks.title: SourceBuffer.videoTracks

sourcebuffer.name: SourceBuffer
sourcebuffer.summary: The SourceBuffer interface represents a chunk of media to be passed into an HTMLMediaElement and played, via a MediaSource object. This can be made up of one or several media segments.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

sourcebuffer.title: SourceBuffer

dom-sourcebufferlist-length.name: length
dom-sourcebufferlist-length.summary: The length read-only property of the SourceBufferList interface returns the number of SourceBuffer objects in the list.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-sourcebufferlist-length.title: SourceBufferList.length

sourcebufferlist.name: SourceBufferList
sourcebufferlist.summary: The SourceBufferList interface represents a simple container list for multiple SourceBuffer objects.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

sourcebufferlist.title: SourceBufferList

dom-videotrack-sourcebuffer.name: sourceBuffer
dom-videotrack-sourcebuffer.summary: The read-only VideoTrack property sourceBuffer returns the SourceBuffer that created the track, or null if the track was not created by a SourceBuffer or the SourceBuffer has been removed from the MediaSource.sourceBuffers attribute of its parent media source.

safari_ios.notes: Exposed in Mobile Safari on iPad but not on iPhone.

dom-videotrack-sourcebuffer.title: VideoTrack.sourceBuffer
